awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Intelligent Fire Detection for Indoor Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will validate the company’s novel fire detection principle and the use of soft computing techniques by means of (1) computational experiments, and (2) a wide range of real fire and nuisance experiments on the company’s fire detector prototypes. This will allow the company to resolve any technical hurdles that may arise from the integration of the software and hardware into a minimum viable fire detector expected to significantly outperform current market solutions. The company has utilized real-world datasets of fire and nuisance experiments conducted by NIST to test and benchmark the innovation. Using temperature data, for example, the company’s algorithm detected fires up to 10 times faster than current technology (fixed-threshold). In addition, no missed detection occurred, and no false alarms were triggered in all NIST experiments. While these results are impressive, they are not sufficient to commercialize the innovation given that they are based on 69 experiments only. The activities proposed in phase I are designed to reduce the technical risk and strengthen the confidence in the company’s technology prior to commercialization. This is especially important because of the high regulatory burden and associated liabilities in the fire detection space.

By leveraging ML, erli.ai’s patent-pending technology will process streaming data from heat/smoke sensors to detect the earliest signs of fire and separate fire and nuisance events. We introduce a new alarm triggering principle rooted in the temporal analysis of sensor data instead of the existing fixed-threshold approach. We propose to further develop our computational architecture, which employs deep Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks and a variational autoencoder, by developing a theoretical basis for the outstanding performance our algorithm produced. We will develop an anomaly detection evaluation scheme for time streaming clustering using Dynamic Time Warping and Similarity Matrix technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2022, the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) reported a staggering 1.5 million fires attended to by U.S. fire departments, with a fire occurring every 21 seconds. Despite constituting only 35% of total incidents, indoor fires accounted for 77% of civilian fire deaths, 88% of injuries, and 83% of property value loss. Residential structures, in particular, saw over 375,000 fires annually, translating to one every 88 seconds, resulting in 2,729 civilian deaths, 9,938 injuries, and $4.8 billion in property damage. Although residential fires comprised just a quarter of all reported fires, they disproportionately caused nearly 72% of civilian fire deaths and 75% of injuries.

The upward trend in residential fire fatalities and injuries is disconcerting. A significant contributing factor is the drastic reduction in available safe egress time, shrinking from 17 minutes in previous decades to as little as 1 to 2 minutes today. Modern construction materials and synthetic furniture contribute to faster and hotter fires, releasing toxic substances and diminishing available oxygen. Smoke inhalation, rather than burns, emerges as the primary cause of fire-related fatalities, with the elderly and individuals with mobility limitations most vulnerable.

Addressing these challenges requires prioritizing early fire detection, a task complicated by the current tradeoff between sensitivity and specificity in today’s sensor technology. Heightened sensitivity, crucial for early detection, escalates the risk of false alarms. In residential settings, cooking-induced fumes often trigger unwarranted alarms, contributing to an astounding 2 million false alarms annually. This not only strains fire departments resources but also leads to occupants disconnecting their smoke detectors to avoid the nuisance. False alarms stand as the primary cause for disconnected detectors, increasing the probability of dying in a home fire by 50% according to the NFPA.

In response to these pressing issues, a critical imperative emerges: the advancement of smoke detection technology to reconcile sensitivity and specificity. This has been the mission of the erli.ai team in this SBIR Phase I research project. Safeguarding lives and property in the face of escalating indoor fire risks is not only a moral obligation but also makes business sense. This is underscored by the ubiquity of smoke detectors, with a global market estimated at USD 4 billion in 2023, and an annual growth rate of 6%. Some of the drivers fueling the increased spending on the protection of assets from fire hazards include increased urbanization, robust infrastructure development, rising number in fire incidents, and stricter government regulations especially pertaining to decreasing the rate of false alarms. While the erli.ai team has concentrated efforts on advancing smoke detection technology for residential applications, acknowledging the inherent challenges of this market sector, the applicability of its technology extends seamlessly into the commercial sector, including hotels, dormitories, hospitals, and elderly housing.

To date, the technology developed at erli.ai does not modify the hardware design of smoke detectors; the photoelectric sensors, their configuration, the smoke chamber and housing designs all stay the same. Instead, erli.ai adds an advanced AI algorithm that is based on a deep learning approach and is implemented on a cheap, ultra-low power microprocessor. The algorithm processes the streaming smoke signals from existing sensors to predict fire versus non-fire events. This innovation allows the tuning of the sensitivity of the detector, which is needed for early detection, without compromising its specificity, which prevents the occurrence of false alarms. This software approach is more cost effective from a certification standpoint, especially considering the high cost involved in certifying new detector designs.

This SBIR Phase I research has successfully developed, implemented, and tested an innovative algorithm in a comparative study where existing residential photoelectric smoke detectors, with and without the erli.ai algorithm, were tested in about 70 fire and cooking nuisance experiments. The chosen detectors are high-end, commercially available, and certified to the latest UL standards. The experiments largely matched those in the latest UL standard, including gray smoke, flaming paper, flaming PU foam, flaming wood, smoldering PU foam, smoldering wood, and broiling frozen hamburgers tests. In addition, several other cooking nuisance tests were conducted. The tests were each repeated about 10 times to ensure robust results.

This empirical proof-of-concept study demonstrates the superior predictive capability of the erli.ai technology. For example, in the flaming paper and flaming PU foam tests, the detectors with the erli.ai algorithm triggered the alarm on average 32 and 37 seconds earlier, respectively, than their unmodified counterparts. This noteworthy enhancement is crucial considering the brief safe egress time of 1-2 minutes, potentially contributing to saving thousands of lives annually in the US alone. Conversely, in the cooking nuisance tests, the detectors with the erli.ai algorithm triggered the alarm on average 107 seconds later than their unmodified counterparts, a desirable outcome to dissuade occupants from disconnecting their smoke detectors.
